title: Lavender Tallow Balm: The Weird Beef Fat Thing My Skin Actually Loves
body:
Okay so. I’m just gonna write this down because I keep telling people about it and sounding like a crazy person. It’s about beef fat. For your face. I know, I know. Just hear me out. Or read me out. Whatever.

It started because my skin was freaking out this winter. Like, tight, itchy, just angry. The heater was on, the air was dry, and my usual stuff—the expensive stuff in the fancy jars—was doing nothing. It was like putting water on sand. My knuckles were cracking. It was a whole thing. I was scrolling on my phone one night, the neighbor’s TV was blaring some reality show through the wall, and I fell down this internet hole. People were talking about tallow balm. Beef tallow skincare. Like, from cows. I remember thinking, “What? Like cooking grease?” It sounded like something my grandma would have had in her pantry, next to the lard. And honestly, that’s kind of where this whole traditional tallow skincare rabbit hole started. With grandmas. Not mine specifically, but like, everyone’s great-great-grandmas.

## How I Ended Up Putting Beef Fat on My Face

So the history bit. I got curious. Why would anyone do this? Turns out, using animal fats on skin isn’t new. It’s ancient. For centuries, before the big skincare companies with their chemical labs, people used what they had. Rendered fat from animals—tallow from cows or sheep—was a base for salves, soaps, everything. It was just… what you used. It’s only in the last hundred years or so that we decided plant oils and synthetic stuff were automatically better. But here’s the thing that made me pause: beef tallow is structurally really close to the oils our own skin makes. Our sebum has a similar fatty acid profile. So the idea is, your skin recognizes it. It’s not a foreign substance trying to trick your face; it’s like giving your skin something familiar it knows how to use. This whole natural skincare comeback isn’t just about being crunchy, sometimes it’s about stuff that just… makes biological sense. Anyway. I was desperate and my skin felt like parchment. I figured, what’s the worst that could happen? I ordered a jar of this whipped tallow balm. The lavender one. From this little Etsy shop that makes it in France. It arrived in this simple jar, no crazy packaging.

I opened it. Here’s where I expected to be grossed out. It looked… like fluffy butter. Seriously. The texture was different. Good different. It’s whipped, so it’s this light, airy cream, not a greasy lump. And the smell? Not beefy. At all. It smelled like lavender. But not like a candle or cheap air freshener. More like… dried lavender from a garden. Herbal. Clean. Simple. It was calming, actually. I put a tiny bit on the back of my hand. It melted. Like, instantly. Didn’t sit on top. Just sank in. My skin drank it. I was shocked. I didn’t expect much but honestly, that first test was promising. No weird residue. Just soft skin.

## What This Lavender Tallow Balm Actually Does

So I started using it. At night. After I wash my face. I’d scoop a little—you don’t need much—warm it between my fingers, and just press it into my skin. The lavender scent is the real genius for a night cream. It’s not overpowering. It’s just this gentle, herbal smell that feels… sleep-promoting. Like it tells your brain it’s time to wind down. My nighttime anxiety, the kind where you’re just replaying dumb conversations from 2012, it kinda quieted a bit. Or maybe I was just more relaxed because my face wasn’t screaming at me. Either way.

The balm itself is made from grass-fed beef suet, whipped into this luxurious texture. That’s it. Maybe some lavender oil. No mile-long ingredient list. Because it mimics human sebum, it absorbs deeply. It doesn’t just coat; it seems to fix the barrier. My dry patches? Gone in like, three days. The fine lines around my eyes—the ones that look worse when I’m dehydrated—they just looked… less noticeable. Not “filled” with something, but like the skin there was just plumper, happier. I started putting it on my hands too. My knuckles healed. No more cracks. It’s good for eczema, I read, and I believe it. It just soothes.

This is a tangent but I used to use this crazy expensive cream, like over a hundred dollars. It had a fancy French name and came in heavy glass. It did nothing. Literally nothing. This stuff in a simple jar, made from beef fat, works better. The irony is not lost on me.

## My Skin After a Few Weeks of This Stuff

I don’t want to sound like an infomercial. But my skin hasn’t been this calm in years. Maybe ever. It’s not “glowing” in that weird, shiny way. It just looks… healthy. Normal. Not red. Not tight. Just content. I wore less makeup because I didn’t feel like I needed to cover up dry flakes. That’s the biggest win for me.

I got brave and used it all over after a shower. Elbows, knees, feet. Game changer. My heels are actually smooth. I’m not kidding. I’m on my second jar now. I told my mom about it and she was horrified at first (“You put what on your face?!”) but then she tried it on her winter-ravaged hands and now she’s asking me for the link. The whole traditional approach, this beef tallow history thing coming full circle, it’s kind of beautiful. We spent decades layering on complex chemicals, and sometimes the answer was in our grandmother’s medicine cabinet the whole time. Or, you know, in a pasture.

## Would I Buy This Lavender Tallow Balm Again?

Yeah. I already did. Look, if your skin is dry, sensitive, or just being difficult, this might be worth a shot. It sounds weird. It is weird. But it works in this simple, no-nonsense way that modern skincare often forgets about. It’s not magic. It’s just good, honest ingredients that happen to be perfectly matched to our skin. The lavender makes it feel like a treat, especially at night. It’s this little ritual now. I’m probably gonna order another one soon just to have as backup. I never want to run out.

## Quick Questions I Get Asked

**Is beef tallow good for your face?**
Weirdly, yes. Because it’s so similar to the oils our skin already makes, it absorbs really well and helps repair the skin barrier. It’s not just sitting on top clogging things. It’s like giving your skin food it recognizes.

**Does tallow balm clog pores?**
I was worried about this too. But no, not for me. Because it absorbs and mimics sebum, it doesn’t just sit there. It’s non-comedogenic. My skin actually feels clearer, maybe because it’s not freaking out and overproducing oil to compensate for being dry.

**What does the lavender tallow balm smell like?**
It smells like real lavender. Herbal, a little earthy, not sweet or perfume-y. It’s calming. Like a garden. It’s not strong, just a nice, natural scent that fades pretty quickly after you put it on.

Anyway. That’s my experience. If you’re curious about this whole natural skincare comeback and want to try something traditional that actually works, this lavender tallow balm might be worth a look. My skin’s happy. I’m happy. That’s all I wanted.
